item.title: Bike shedding or Parkinson’s Law of Triviality
item.description:
Bike shedding also known as Parkinson’s Law of Triviality occurs when members of a team give disproportionate weight to trivial issues when bigger issues are up for discussion.

The term bike shedding came about through Parkinson’s fictional story of a committee who had to approve plans for a nuclear power plant, but preferred to discuss about a bike shed instead because the problem was easier to grasp.

Not to be confused with Parkinson’s Law

Reference

  • Law of triviality

item.title: Parkinson’s Law
item.description:
Parkinson’s Law states that “work expands to fill the time available for its completion.”

Not to be confused with Parkinson’s Law of Triviality

Reference

  • Parkinson’s Law

item.title: Peter Principle
item.description:
Peter Principle states that people, in a company, are promoted to their “level of incompetence.” This is because an employee is promoted based on the success of their previous job until they reach a level at which they are no longer competent.

Reference

Peter Principle
